update.description:
`common::Timer` returns the elapsed time between when the timer was started and when it was stopped (or the current time). This pull request gives `Timer` the option to be initialized as a "countdown" timer. A "countdown" timer has a `maxTime` variable representing the time that the `Timer` counts down from. It tracks the start and stop time, but returns the "elapsed" time as the time elapsed from the `maxTime`.

The countdown timer is now accessible through the `TimerGUIPlugin` by specifying a `countdown_time` in SDF:

```
<countdown_time>(seconds) (nanoseconds)</countdown_time>
```

You can test this pull request by enabling the `TimerGUIPlugin` overlay with this SDF block:

```
      <plugin name="TimerGUIPlugin" filename="libTimerGUIPlugin.so">
        <size>155 80</size>
        <start_stop_button>1</start_stop_button>
       <reset_button>1</reset_button>
        <topic>~/timer_control</topic>
        <countdown_time>60 1000</countdown_time>
      </plugin>
```
update.title: Add countdown feature to common::Timer, expose countdown to TimerGUIPlugin

content.raw:
I just saw the timer tests fail on trusty too, though much closer to the tolerance ([no-gpu job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/322/)):
~~~
79: [ RUN      ] TimerTest.Timer
79: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/gazebo/gazebo/common/Timer_TEST.cc:41: Failure
79: The difference between elapsed.nsec and 2e8 is 113353, which exceeds 1e5, where
79: elapsed.nsec evaluates to 200113353,
79: 2e8 evaluates to 200000000, and
79: 1e5 evaluates to 100000.
79: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/gazebo/gazebo/common/Timer_TEST.cc:48: Failure
79: The difference between elapsed.nsec and timer.GetElapsed().nsec is 262487, which exceeds 1e5, where
79: elapsed.nsec evaluates to 200113353,
79: timer.GetElapsed().nsec evaluates to 200375840, and
79: 1e5 evaluates to 100000.
79: [  FAILED  ] TimerTest.Timer (401 ms)
79: [ RUN      ] TimerTest.CountdownTimer
79: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/gazebo/gazebo/common/Timer_TEST.cc:78: Failure
79: The difference between elapsed.nsec and 8e8 is 114932, which exceeds 1e5, where
79: elapsed.nsec evaluates to 799885068,
79: 8e8 evaluates to 800000000, and
79: 1e5 evaluates to 100000.
79: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/gazebo/gazebo/common/Timer_TEST.cc:85: Failure
79: The difference between elapsed.nsec and timer.GetElapsed().nsec is 166995, which exceeds 1e5, where
79: elapsed.nsec evaluates to 799885068,
79: timer.GetElapsed().nsec evaluates to 799718073, and
79: 1e5 evaluates to 100000.
79: [  FAILED  ] TimerTest.CountdownTimer (401 ms)
~~~

content.raw:
I created #1626 to track the OS X problems, and I suggest the following patch to disable the test for OS X:

~~~
diff -r 7878b71b3db2 gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt	Tue Jun 02 16:20:46 2015 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt	Tue Jun 02 17:43:35 2015 -0700
@@ -138,9 +138,17 @@
   SystemPaths_TEST.cc
   SVGLoader_TEST.cc
   Time_TEST.cc
-  Timer_TEST.cc
 )
 
+# Timer test fails on OSX
+# See issue #1626
+if (NOT APPLE)
+  set (gtest_sources
+    ${gtest_sources}
+    Timer_TEST.cc
+  )
+endif()
+
 if (HAVE_GTS)
 set (sources
   ${sources}
~~~
content.html:
I created #1626 to track the OS X problems, and I suggest the following patch to disable the test for OS X:

diff -r 7878b71b3db2 gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt  Tue Jun 02 16:20:46 2015 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt  Tue Jun 02 17:43:35 2015 -0700
@@ -138,9 +138,17 @@
   SystemPaths_TEST.cc
   SVGLoader_TEST.cc
   Time_TEST.cc
-  Timer_TEST.cc
 )

+# Timer test fails on OSX
+# See issue #1626
+if (NOT APPLE)
+  set (gtest_sources
+    ${gtest_sources}
+    Timer_TEST.cc
+  )
+endif()
+
 if (HAVE_GTS)
 set (sources
   ${sources}

content.raw:
Alright, I don't have an OSX machine so I can't test this directly, but here's my idea: the `Time` test doesn't cover `Time::Sleep`, only setting the time based on operators and getting the current time. I wonder if `Time::Sleep` is broken on OSX.

Shall I write a test for this or are you on it?
content.html:
Alright, I don't have an OSX machine so I can't test this directly, but here's my idea: the Time test doesn't cover Time::Sleep, only setting the time based on operators and getting the current time. I wonder if Time::Sleep is broken on OSX.

Shall I write a test for this or are you on it?

79: [  FAILED  ] TimerTest.CountdownTimer (408 ms)

pull_request.title: Add countdown feature to common::Timer, expose countdown to TimerGUIPlugin

update.description:
`common::Timer` returns the elapsed time between when the timer was started and when it was stopped (or the current time). This pull request gives `Timer` the option to be initialized as a "countdown" timer. A "countdown" timer has a `maxTime` variable representing the time that the `Timer` counts down from. It tracks the start and stop time, but returns the "elapsed" time as the time elapsed from the `maxTime`.

The countdown timer is now accessible through the `TimerGUIPlugin` by specifying a `countdown_time` in SDF:

```
<countdown_time>(seconds) (nanoseconds)</countdown_time>
```

You can test this pull request by enabling the `TimerGUIPlugin` overlay with this SDF block:

```
      <plugin name="TimerGUIPlugin" filename="libTimerGUIPlugin.so">
        <size>155 80</size>
        <start_stop_button>1</start_stop_button>
       <reset_button>1</reset_button>
        <topic>~/timer_control</topic>
        <countdown_time>60 1000</countdown_time>
      </plugin>
```
update.title: Add countdown feature to common::Timer, expose countdown to TimerGUIPlugin

content.html:
Oh I see, I didn't try the code. But it's good to know this about negative times, in case we want to jump back in time during log playback.

How about something like this?

  // If out of time
  if (elapsedTime > this->maxTime)
    elapsedTime = Time(0);
  else
    elapsedTime = this->maxTime - elapsedTime;

content.raw: The only thing about this code snippet is that Time cannot go negative because of time `Time::Correct` call in `Time::operator -`.
content.html: The only thing about this code snippet is that Time cannot go negative because of time Time::Correct call in Time::operator -.

content.html:
I think you reduce some code duplication doing something like this (I haven't tried it though)

Time elapsedTime;
if (this->running)
  elapsedTime = Time::GetWallTime() - this->start;
else
  elapsedTime = this->stop - this->start;

// If we're counting down, return the countdown time minus the total
// elapsed time.
if (this->countdown)
{
  elapsedTime = this->maxTime - elapsedTime;

  // If out of time
  if (elapsedTime < 0)
    elapsedTime = Time(0);
}
return elapsedTime;

pullrequest.title: Add countdown feature to common::Timer, expose countdown to TimerGUIPlugin

content.raw:
Yeah, it's a bit confusing.

By default, GetElapsed does what you expect: it starts at 0 and counts up.

This pull request adds the ability to initialize a timer as a "countdown", which means that GetElapsed some maximum time and then counts down.

This part of the test tests the countdown functionality. The earlier portion of the test counts the default functionality.

I'm receptive to implementing this in a less messy way; this was just a convenient way to get a countdown timer in the TimerGUIPlugin.
content.html:
Yeah, it's a bit confusing.

By default, GetElapsed does what you expect: it starts at 0 and counts up.

This pull request adds the ability to initialize a timer as a "countdown", which means that GetElapsed some maximum time and then counts down.

This part of the test tests the countdown functionality. The earlier portion of the test counts the default functionality.

I'm receptive to implementing this in a less messy way; this was just a convenient way to get a countdown timer in the TimerGUIPlugin.

pullrequest.title: Add countdown feature to common::Timer, expose countdown to TimerGUIPlugin

content.raw: I added a Timer unit test in b7be52a and noticed that there was a bug with stopping and starting the timer. The start time wasn't getting adjusted on stop, so starting the timer after stopping for a time would cause the time to "jump" forward (because it was measuring relative to the original start time). I fixed it in that commit. Let me know if you have any questions.
content.html: I added a Timer unit test in b7be52a and noticed that there was a bug with stopping and starting the timer. The start time wasn't getting adjusted on stop, so starting the timer after stopping for a time would cause the time to "jump" forward (because it was measuring relative to the original start time). I fixed it in that commit. Let me know if you have any questions.
